questiontext.text:
An experiment was performed to test the effect of two treatments on the yield. The two treatments are fertiliser and variety. There are three levels of fertiliser, and two different varieties.

The task is to use the data below to answer the following questions using pivot tables to investigate how the treatments affect the yield.

Download Data


1. What is the {@quest_expr1@} yield obtained from the experiment? Give your answer to \(2\text{dp}\)

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

[[feedback:prt1]]

2. What is the {@quest_expr2@} yield for Variety \(1\)? Give your answer to \(2\text{dp}\)

[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

[[feedback:prt2]]

3. What is the {@quest_expr3@} yield for Variety \(1\) when Fertiliser \(1\) is used? Give your answer to \(2\text{dp}\)

[[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]

[[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text: Full details on how to create and use Pivot tables can be found here.

questionnote.text:
What is the {@quest_expr1@} yield? Give to \(2\text{dp}\) = {@ta_1@}

What is the {@quest_expr2@} yield for Variety \(1\)? = {@ta_2@}

What is the {@quest_expr3@} yield for Variety \(1\) when Fertiliser \(1\) is used? = {@ta_3@}

questiondescription.text:
Mary Sayuni

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1M1PSU_3ENRT4V35PLR4JsBVKLyTa6S3InVDAW4Hsqwg/edit#heading=h.vy8x1tbmoha9

Dan Kelly

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

truefeedback.text: Your answer is correct, but do note that the question stated to give to \(2\text{dp}\).

Not quite, the question asking for the {@quest_expr1@} of the yield.
In a pivot table in Excel this can be achieved by clicking on the yield variable in the “Values” field, and selecting “Value Field Settings...”.
See here for an example in Excel.

falsefeedback.text:
Not quite. This can be achieved in spreadsheet software with PivotTables quite nicely.
For example, see here how to set up PivotTables in Excel.
Here, we have just one variable, Yield, that we want to look at the summary of. So we just have to enter “Yield” into the “Value” box, and select the appropriate statistic.

node.description: checks for correct summary of variety 1

truefeedback.text: You have correctly found the {@quest_expr2@} yield for variety \(1\).

node.description: checks for correct answer not to 2dp

truefeedback.text: Your answer is correct, but do note that the question stated to give to \(2\text{dp}\).

Not quite, the question asking for the {@quest_expr2@} of the yield.
In a pivot table in Excel this can be achieved by clicking on the yield variable in the “Values” field, and selecting “Value Field Settings...”.
See here for an example in Excel.

node.description: check for summary yield of all data

truefeedback.text:
Close, you have correctly found the {@quest_expr2@} yield overall. But we want to look at just for variety \(1\).
This could be achieved by using the “Filter”, “Rows”, or “Columns” field if you put the "Variety" variable in it.

falsefeedback.text:
Not quite. This can be achieved in spreadsheet software with PivotTables quite nicely.
For example, see here how to set up PivotTables in Excel.
Here,"Variety" variable needs to be dragged into either rows or columns because we are interested in the maximum yield for Variety 1. we have just one variable, Yield, that we want to look at the summary of. So we just have to enter “Yield” into the “Value” box, and select the appropriate statistic.

node.description: checks for correct summary of variety 1 with fertiliser 1

truefeedback.text: You have correctly found the {@quest_expr3@} yield for variety \(1\) with fertiliser \(1\).

node.description: checks for correct answer not to 2dp

truefeedback.text: Your answer is correct, but do note that the question stated to give to \(2\text{dp}\).

Not quite, the question asking for the {@quest_expr3@} of the yield.
In a pivot table in Excel this can be achieved by clicking on the yield variable in the “Values” field, and selecting “Value Field Settings...”.
See here for an example in Excel.

node.description: check for summary yield of all data

truefeedback.text:
Close, you have correctly found the {@quest_expr3@} yield overall. But we want to look at just for variety \(1\) with fertiliser \(1\).
This could be achieved by using the “Filter”, “Rows”, or “Columns” field if you put both "Variety" and "Fertiliser" variables in. It can be clearer to read if you put the two variables in different fields (e.g. one in Rows, one in Columns).

node.description: checks for summary of variety 1 with fertiliser 2

truefeedback.text: Nearly! But it appears you have considered the {@quest_expr3@} yield for Variety \(1\) when Fertiliser \(2\) is used, whereas you should have considered when Fertiliser \(1\) is used.

falsefeedback.text:
Not quite. This can be achieved in a spreadsheet software with PivotTables quite nicely.
For example, see here how to set PivotTables up in Excel.
Here, we want to look at the summary of the yield. So we just have to enter “Yield” into the “Value” box, and select the appropriate statistic.
We want to look at the summary for Variety \(1\) and Fertiliser \(1\). This could be achieved by using the “Filter”, “Rows”, or “Columns” field if you put both Variety and Fertiliser variables in. It can be clearer to read if you put the two variables in different fields (e.g., one in rows, one in columns).
